addressleaf.section: To the right honorable my singular good Lord the L Burghley, Lord highe Treasuror of England.

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
L. although I doe not omitte
to advertise
M
r
Secretary
, of w
at
soever passeth
in this place of any moment, whiche I persuade
my self alwaies is imparted w
t
yo
r
L. Yet in
regard of advancing her
Ma
ties
service, I can not
otherwise choose, but when occasions are presented,
interrupt yo
r
most weighty affaires, w
t
my tro-
blesome letters. In whiche respect I doe not thinke
that I have had heeretofore a more important occa-
sion, then is offered at this present.
For it is
certified hither that
e Enemie hath receaved a
full pay of all his Arrerages, and that he hath sent
from
Andwerp
towardes
Bolducke
32 peeces
of great artillerie, and maketh great provision of
flat bottome boates, Waggons, and bridges, and other
necessaries for a siege and passage of rivers, w
ch
is generally thought to be for
Huesden,
and
Bommels
Weert
, albeit we have advertisments that he like-
wise intendeth a surprise of
e Iles of
Tertolen,
and
Tergoes
, where it is said that he hath sent of
late very secretly to sounde
e depth of
e waters.
Whatsoever is purposed, I doe finde that these men heer
are greatly perplexed for want of men and meanes:
and though heeretofore
e presumptuous conceats
of some of
e prinicpall among them, hath caried
away
e rest, to take Undutifull courses against
her Ma
tie
yet if
e Enemie should prevaile in
any of
e forsaid exploits, it may be judged by
some tokens of humblenes, w
ch
they shewe at this
present, that they will flie to her Ma
tie
for succo
r
,
and omitte no submission to be further assisted.
Wheruppon,
e opportunitie serving, I thought to take
fol.5v
occasion to declare my opinion to yo
r
L concer-
ning their proceeding in those Articles, w
ch
were
sent me lately from my Lordes. It is nowe a moneth
since that they were delivered to
e
Generall states
,
and I have moved them often to make an ans-
wear to her Ma
tie
. But they doe alwaies alleage,
that they have had no answear from their Princi-
pals: whiche if they listed, and were a mater to
their liking, they could easely procure, and in
lesse then half the time. I doe very muche
dout heeruppon, that ether they have not, as they pro-
mised, sent the Articles to their Principals, or els
they purposely delay to call uppon them for an
answear. For by all that I can conjecture, these
that are
e chiefest Leaders among them, are ut-
terly unwilling, to admiite any newe resoluc
o
ns
or constructions in
e Treaty: misdouting that w
ch
must ensewe of necessitie, that they will be dero-
gatorie to that autoritie which they usurpe uppon
e
Councell
. To give yo
r
L. to un-
derstand w
at
I do finde by some c
o
ference, whiche
I have had of these maters, There are divers in this
place of good discrec
o
n and calling, who thinke it
altogether needeles for her Ma
tie
to enter into consul-
tation w
t
any Deputies from hens, about
e re-
dresse of
e Treaty, or suche other demaundes, as
the Articles import. But considering to w
at
extre-
mitie these contreis are like to be reduced, and
in w
at
devotion
e generalitie doth continew to her
Ma
tie
if it might please her to sett downe perempto-
rily, w
t
out using their advise, and to declare di-
fol.6r
rectly by her letters to
e Generall states, and to
e Councell of state, to
e states of
e particular
Provinces, and to
e principall townes, First in
what maner she hath alwaies Understood
e meaning
of
e Treaty, and howe she doth expect, that it
should be observed: and secondly, w
at
further mater
she will have them yeld Unto, in respect of their
owne securitie, and
e better governm
t
of
e contrey:
and theruppon will promise
at they shall be pro-
tected w
t
suche assistance as is mentioned in
e
Treaty: doutles it is thought
at suche a resolute
kinde of pr oceeding, will sooner take place, then those
orderly courses w
ch
her Ma
tie
doth propose. For it is
most manifest to every man heere,
at
e farre grea-
test part, not of
e common people only, but of the
chiefest persons in these contreis,
that
doe not thinke
that their Pensioners and Deputies are so willfull,
and so precisely and perversly bent, as to stand
w
t
her Ma
tie
uppon pointes of no greater prejudice
to
e state of these contreis, and
yet
full of hindraunce
to
e common resistance w
ch
is made against
e Enemie.
This is
e effect of suche talke, as I have had w
t
sundrie that are heere, men of experience and
good Understanding: w
t
whose opinions I thought
it my duty to acquaint yo
r
L. and so to leave it
to be further considered, as yo
r
L. wisdome shall
finde it expedient:
wherw
t
I take my humble
leave. From
e Hage 2 August 89.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
